aboutMe.quote:
Wow, you draw so beautifully!
Could you draw something for me too?
aboutMe.phrase1: â€“ perhaps this was the most motivating phrase throughout my childhood. In school, I always couldn't wait for art class and breaks, as that's when I could truly be the star of the class. Somehow it all started from there, from tigers drawn with black markers.
aboutMe.phrase2: Later I set out in the primitive tattoo world of Hungary without formal training, with a portfolio of drawn designs and unwavering determination, at the age of 17. Many turned me away, a few helped, and during the Balaton summer seasons, I was allowed quite close to the action. I first officially started working as a tattoo artist with the Celtic Moon Tattoo team, working alongside James, from whom I truly learned this wonderful profession.
aboutMe.phrase3: In the absence of art schools, I learned a lot through tattooing, but perhaps I even discovered myself.
aboutMe.phrase4: Many years have passed since then, and now I work in my own studio, occasionally guest tattooing abroad, and I am very happy to be a tattoo artist. ðŸ˜¸

info.title: Information
info.summary:
One client per day
-What does my work process look like?
text:
One client per day 
 -What does my work process look like?

info.title: Design.
info.summary:
We meet at the shop at 11 AM to discuss your ideas.
During our conversation, I create the design to make the final result more personalized.

When we are both satisfied with the design, the actual tattooing begins.
text: We meet at the shop at 11 AM, sit down, and chat a bit. I ask what you would like to get tattooed, what your idea is, whether you have a specific image or just examples, or perhaps neither. Sometimes the images brought along aren't the best quality or aren't as expressive for the requested theme, in which case I help and suggest better ideas.
A beautiful picture may look good on a wall but doesn't necessarily work well as a tattoo.

During our conversation, I create the design (I draw by hand or edit on the computer). This might take 1-2 hours, but during this time I get to know you a bit, and the result will be more personalized.
When the design is ready and we are both satisfied with it, we begin the tattooing.

info.title: Tattooing.
info.summary:
We take breaks hourly, allowing time to eat and drink. This is important because you'll typically spend 4-6 hours with me.

For pain relief, you can bring medication that you're familiar with, but let's discuss it.
text: We take breaks roughly every hour so we can eat and drink (my shop has a kitchen with a refrigerator and microwave), so you can bring food or order it. This is important because you typically spend 4-6 hours with me, and it's not a good idea to stay hungry as you might feel unwell!

For pain relief, you can bring medication that you know works for you (Flector, Advil, Cataflam, etc.). I don't use lidocaine-based numbing agents, so if you're planning to use something like that, please let's discuss it.
What's much more important is that you come well-rested and mentally prepared!

info.title: Finishing.
info.summary: At the end of the day, I wash your tattoo with antiseptic soap and then cover it with a special tattoo bandage called Dry lock pad, after which we discuss aftercare.
text: When the artwork is complete, or the day's planned continuation is finished, I wash your tattoo with antiseptic soap and photograph it (these photos may be uploaded to the internet as part of my portfolio, of course without faces and names, and I don't tag anyone on social media).
Afterward, I cover it with a special tattoo bandage called Dry lock pad, we discuss the aftercare, and I provide printed instructions for you to take home.

info.title: Aftercare.
info.summary:
The protective bandage can be removed after 8 hours, then wash the tattooed area with water, possibly with antiseptic soap as well. 
 Then apply Bepanthten cream 3 times daily with clean hands for 1-1.5 weeks.
text: The protective bandage (dry lock pad) can be removed after 8 hours, then wash the tattooed area with water, possibly with antiseptic soap as well.

Don't use a towel for drying! Let it air dry if possible, then apply a thin layer of Bepanthten cream (I don't recommend the ointment as it's too greasy and doesn't absorb well). By thin layer, I mean there shouldn't be excess cream sitting on the skin! (Use other healing creams only if you're allergic to Bepanthen, and only after discussing it with me)
Apply cream 3 times daily with clean hands!
Maximum 1-1.5 weeks.
After that, it's advisable to continue moisturizing the skin with body lotion.

list.title: PROHIBITED (first 2-3 days):
items: picking at the wound, exposing it to infection

list.title: (2-3 weeks):
items: scratching (itching is normal, it's part of the healing process)

text2: In the long term, all tattoos are damaged by the sun's UV radiation, so it's recommended to avoid tanning beds and sunbathing on the tattooed area, and use high SPF sunscreen.

After getting a tattoo, the skin's epithelial layer regenerates for 6 months, so it's not as thick and doesn't provide as much protection to the body as intact skin! During this time, it must be protected by covering it from the sun, sunscreen alone is not enough!
If there are any issues, speak up, ask questions!!!

info.title: Financials.
info.summary:
Design â€“ 5,000 HUF/hour
Tattooing â€“ 20,000 HUF/hour
Minimum daily fee â€“ 50,000 HUF / Maximum daily fee â€“ 100,000 HUF
text: I've tried to come up with a fair pricing system that falls between hourly and daily rates, so you can approach me for both smaller* and larger tattoos.
Design â€“ 5,000 HUF/hour
Tattooing â€“ 20,000 HUF/hour
Minimum daily fee â€“ 50,000 HUF
Maximum daily fee â€“ 100,000 HUF

info.title: What kind of requests should you choose me for?
info.summary:
What suits me: Living things â€“ animals, people, fictional creatures. 'In style' â€“ realistic (lifelike), surreal, fairy-tale-like (cartoon-like, comic-book style). I also like new trends! * I enjoy creating both colored and black and white works.

What doesn't suit me: Traditional tribal patterns â€“ Maori, Japanese (these historically significant patterns have complex symbol systems that I know little about)
Horror themes or negative topics.

What I won't accept: Continuing, fixing, or covering up another tattoo artist's work.
Cover-ups only in very unique cases where I can see that I can create a full-value end result. (Here I often recommend laser fading first, which can take a long time, but I can design much prettier solutions on it.)
Text/lettering, tiny tattoos (just a few centimeters).
*If I can create several smaller tattoos in one day on one client, that's certainly possible.
text: Since I've been tattooing for a long time, my work is versatile, and I haven't strictly specialized in one style. Of course, I have tasks that suit me better (body and soul), so I'll give preference to these and there will be requests that I decline.
What suits me:

<div>Living things â€“ animals, people, fictional creatures. </br> 'In style' â€“ realistic (lifelike), surreal, fairy-tale-like (cartoon-like, comic-book style). </br> I also like new trends! * </br> I enjoy creating both colored and black and white works.
What doesn't suit me:
<div>Traditional tribal patterns â€“ Maori, Japanese (these historically significant patterns have complex symbol systems that I know little about) </br> Horror themes or negative topics. </br> <div>
What I won't accept:

Continuing, fixing, or covering up another tattoo artist's work.
Cover-ups only in very unique cases where I can see that I can create a full-value end result. (Here I often recommend laser fading first, which can take a long time, but I can design much prettier solutions on it.)
Text/lettering, tiny tattoos (just a few centimeters).
*If I can create several smaller tattoos in one day on one client, that's certainly possible.

info.title: Why is your patience important?
info.summary:
You can only book with me via email.

In August I release appointments from September through January.
In December I release appointments from January through May

In summer I work less, by individual arrangement, for two technical reasons: I rest, and the summer sun almost completely ruins my fresh work
text: Over the years, many of you have come to love my work and more and more people reach out to me. I'm very happy about this because I can create and fulfill myself every day. What's difficult, however, is efficiently organizing my time.
A tattoo isn't a loaf of bread, and I'm on my own for every task.
text2: So it's best to write to me in August and December because that's when I can effectively deal with it.

list.title: Therefore, I work according to the following system:
items: you can only book with me via email
In August I release appointments from September through January
In December I release appointments from January through May
In summer I work less, by individual arrangement, for two technical reasons: I rest, and the summer sun almost completely ruins my fresh work

info.title: "When can you give me an appointment, how long is the waiting list?"

items: if you didn't get an appointment or perhaps a response to your email, please don't be offended; if you're sure I would gladly take on your request, write again! It's possible I didn't notice it, you didn't get processed, etc.
when I reopen my calendar, I will always first schedule clients whose tattoos are still unfinished or whose appointments had to be canceled (e.g., due to illness)

text2: If you've read all this, you've already helped me a lot in my work so I can spend more time tattooing! ðŸ™‚
